name: amireallyvulnerable
description: ‘Am I Really Vulnerable?’ is a python open source project that comes to meet the need of validating if your system is vulnerable to specific vulnerabilities. The project can help you understand whether you are vulnerable to a specific vulnerability and explain to you what is the vulnerable component or invulnerable component in your system. The project can create a graph that presents the validation flow according to the vulnerability checks we perform. We want to create a community of researchers and programmers that can add vulnerability checks for new vulnerabilities or critical or famous vulnerabilities. Whenever a new vulnerability comes up, we can offer this service that helps people validate if they are vulnerable or not. In addition, the vulnerabilities checks we wrote so far, can be expanded with some checks we might have missed.

name: CredSweeper
description: CredSweeper is a tool to detect credentials in any directories or files. CredSweeper could help users to detect unwanted exposure of credentials (such as personal information, token, passwords, api keys and etc) in advance. By scanning lines, filtering, and using AI model as option, CredSweeper reports lines with possible credentials, where the line is, and expected type of the credential as a result.

name: actions-runner-controller
description: Kubernetes controller for GitHub Actions self-hosted runners
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/actions-runner-controller/actions-runner-controller/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
contribution_requirements_justification: We require evidence that the patch works, including steps to test the change locally. We don't have a defined coding standard, but we require code reviews from maintainers so incorrectly styled code are rejected via reviews. Please also refer to https://github.com/actions-runner-controller/actions-runner-controller/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-to-contribute-a-patch
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/actions-runner-controller/actions-runner-controller/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: We provide full documentation via our README https://github.com/actions-runner-controller/actions-runner-controller#actions-runner-controller-arc
documentation_interface_justification: We use Kubernetes CRDs as the API to configure the software as described in https://github.com/actions-runner-controller/actions-runner-controller#usage
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification:
We release a new version of the "canary" container image for each new commit to our master branch, so that anyone can test the unreleased edge version of the software and report any bugs to GitHub Issues.
We build such canary images by using GitHub Actions, as implemented in https://github.com/actions-runner-controller/actions-runner-controller/blob/master/.github/workflows/wip.yml
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: We use semver and publish release for two things, the primary software written in Golang, and another for the Helm chart that wraps the software into a K8s package. As you can see in https://github.com/actions-runner-controller/actions-runner-controller/releases, both of those are versioned uniquely.
version_tags_justification: We tag git commits with version numbers.
report_tracker_justification: We're using GitHub Issues as the issue tracker
report_process_justification: We provide a bug report form https://github.com/actions-runner-controller/actions-runner-controller/issues/new?assignees=&labels=bug&template=bug_report.yml&title=Bug
report_responses_justification: We acknowledge most of the bugs in a day or two
enhancement_responses_justification: We respond most of the feature requests in a day or two
report_archive_justification:
You can view old reports in GitHub Issues
https://github.com/actions-runner-controller/actions-runner-controller/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aclosed+
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: The reporter is encouraged to use e-mail for private communication as documented in https://github.com/actions-runner-controller/actions-runner-controller/blob/master/SECURITY.md#reporting-a-vulnerability
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: N/A, we've never had vulnerabilities yet
build_floss_tools_justification: The project can be built by using Golang only, which is a FLOSS provided by Google.
test_justification:
We use GitHub Actions for CI and builds are automatically ran against every pull request submitted by the user.
Also, there's a detailed instruction on how to run tests locally in our CONTRIBUTING.md
https://github.com/actions-runner-controller/actions-runner-controller/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#testing-controller-built-from-a-pull-request
test_invocation_justification: The test suite can be run via `go test`, which is the standard way to run tests for Golang
test_policy_justification:
Every new feature needs evidence (the test procedure and the testdata that is used to test the new feature locally and the expected result) for every new feature, as documented in https://github.com/actions-runner-controller/actions-runner-controller/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-to-contribute-a-patch

We only include major features in our automated test suite due to financial reasons(some test requires a real server that costs hundreds dollars per month when run regularly so we only run tests that are possible within the free GitHub Actions environment).

We do test every new feature manually before each release though.
tests_documented_added_justification: Automated tests are generally written by maintainers so that they can better understand how the new features and bug fixes work. So, we don't require contributors to write tests themselves.
warnings_fixed_justification: The maintainer addresses any warnings found by `go vet`
warnings_strict_justification: We run all the checks provided by `go vet`
know_secure_design_justification:
The project's primary maintainer is Yusuke Kuoka (a.k.a @mumoshu) who has experience in managing secure production Kubernetes clusters for various industries including messaging and financial services, and developing and running various secure Kubernetes controllers written in Golang on those clusters.

The project "actions-runner-controller" is supposed to run in a Kubernetes cluster and written in Golang. The primary maintainer has production experience in both of those, and applies many security practices like correctly designed Kubernetes custom resources and RBAC onto the project.
delivery_unsigned_justification: We use GitHub release assets to publish hashes over https.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: `go vet` provides a few rules to detect potential issues due to unsafe cgo usage or concurrency bugs. We don't use Go's unsafe features at all and concurrency bugs are expected to be discovered via our test suite. Also, we rely on K8s' validation to not accept invalid user inputs that may lead to vulnerabilities if handled inappropriately.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: We address vulnerabilities according to our policy documented at https://github.com/actions-runner-controller/actions-runner-controller/blob/master/SECURITY.md
static_analysis_often_justification: We do run static analysis on every change for a part of our project(helm chart)
dynamic_analysis_justification: We run gofuzz for dynamic analysis
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: We use Go and don't rely on CGO or unsafe features so it's memory-safe
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: We use go's race detector while running unit tests to detect some of issues covered by dynamic analysis
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: We use GitHub Actions for CI.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
english_justification:
We provide documentation in English: https://github.com/actions-runner-controller/actions-runner-controller#actions-runner-controller-arc
We accept bug reports and comments in English: https://github.com/actions-runner-controller/actions-runner-controller/issues/new/choose
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.
maintained_justification: The primary maintainer of the project (Yusuke Kuoka a.k.a @mumoshu) works 5 days per week on the project, and the co-maintainer @toast-gear works almost 3-4 days per week on the project. We review 2-3 PRs a day and reply to comments in a day or two. I think that's much better than most of the open-source projects that are maintained by volunteers who have other full-time jobs.

name: calico
description: Cloud native networking and network security

Licensed under Apache 2.0: https://github.com/projectcalico/calico/blob/master/calico/LICENSE

Described further in the README: https://github.com/projectcalico/calico#license

Calico is open source, with most code and documentation available under the Apache 2.0 license (see the LICENSE), though some elements are necessarily licensed under different open source licenses for compatibility with upstream licensing or code linking. For example, some Calico BPF programs are licensed under GPL v2.0 for compatibility with Linux kernel helper functions.
